Title: Transcendence: My SpiritualExperiences with Pramukh Swamiji
Author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
Description: This book is Kalam’s Spiritualmemoir of his reflections and experiences with Pramukh Swami Maharaj over fourteen years. It explores how the Spiritualleader inspired him, especially in how science and spirituality can coexist in service to society. It is divided into sections: personal Spiritualexperiences, BAPS’s community and their works, fusion of science and spirituality, and reflections on Business. Kalam writes with humility and insight, giving both intimate anecdotes and broader thoughts on faith, purpose, and integrity.

Title: My Journey: Transforming Dreams into Actions
Author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
Description: This is a collection of anecdotes and personal reflections by Kalam, tracing his life from childhood in Rameswaram to his role as President of India. He shares key moments that shaped his valueswork ethic, humility, curiosity, faith, setbacks and successes. The book is presented in short chapters, accessible and Inspirationalgeared towards motivating youth by showing how dreams followed by deliberate action can transform one's life. It combines narrative, moral lessons, and glimpses into both scientific work and public service

Title: Wings of Fire
Author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
Description: Wings of Fire is the autobiography of A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, tracing his rise from modest beginnings in Rameswaram, through his education and early work, to becoming a leading scientist and eventually India’s President. It describes his experiences in India’s space and missile programmes, the challenges, mistakes, and human aspects of scientific endeavour. The book is inspiring for its emphasis on perseverance, integrity, and dreams supported by hard work. It also reflects Kalam’s humility, his love for his family, and his deep sense of service.

Title: Ignited Minds
Author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
Description: Ignited Minds is written as an inspiring call to the youth of India, urging them to overcome the inertia that holds back the nation. Kalam examines current attitudesfear of failure, lack of initiative, reliance on the averagearguing that India’s greatest challenge is mindset as much as material deficit. He uses stories of visionaries, scientists, teachers, and saints to illustrate how dreams convert into action. The book mixes personal anecdotes, Inspirational messages, and practical ideas, with emphasis on education, innovation, and national unity. Ultimately, it aims to awaken the latent power within every Indian to contribute to a dynamic, prosperous, and equitable society.

Title: Indomitable Spirit
Author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
Description: Indomitable Spirit brings together Dr. Kalam’s speeches, addresses, and thoughts reflecting his ideals, values, and vision for India. It’s arranged into chapters dealing with themes like education, science & spirituality, creative Business, empowered youth, and enlightened citizenship. Throughout the book, Kalam encourages overcoming the “defeatist spirit,” urging readers to face challenges with hope, perseverance, and courage. The style is Inspirational, peppered with anecdotes of people who embody these ideals, and reflects Kalam’s belief in the potential of ordinary individuals to contribute to national Self Development

Title: The Papers of Benjamin Franklin
Author: Benjamin Franklin
Description: The Papers of Benjamin Franklin is an authoritative, annotated collection of Franklin’s complete writingspersonal letters, Politicalcorrespondence, scientific Essays, and public documents. Edited by scholars, it provides context, cross-references, and History notes, making it an invaluable resource for researchers and historians. It sheds light on Franklin’s multifaceted life as a printer, scientist, diplomat, and Founding Father. The series is one of the most ambitious documentary editing projects in American history.

Title: Poor Richard's Almanack
Author: Benjamin Franklin
Description: Poor Richard’s Almanack is a yearly publication Benjamin Franklin issued between 1732-1758 under the pseudonym “Poor Richard” (Richard Saunders). It combined weather forecasts, practical advice for daily life, proverbs, puzzles, and aphorisms. Many of the sayings (“A penny saved is a penny earned,” etc.) became deeply embedded in American culture. It reflects Franklin’s wit, moral Philosophy, and entrepreneurial spirit.

Title: Benjamin Franklin: Writings
Author: Benjamin Franklin
Description: This is a large, authoritative single-volume collection of Franklin’s writings, including Poor Richard’s Almanack, his Autobiography, various pamphlets, Essays, letters, and later Politicaland diplomatic correspondence. Edited by J. A. Leo Lemay, it aims to present Franklin’s works in their History and literary context, preserving his style and original intent. The edition is aesthetically distinguished (acid-free paper, Smyth-sewn binding) and designed for durability and close reading. It offers readers a deep window into early American thought, republican values, the invention of self-improvement, and Franklin’s public life.

The story explores how each woman charts her own path, the cost of following romantic ideals, and the different forms love can take in an era of strict social norms.

Childhood friends George Dashwood and Amelia Dennison shared summers roaming the Sussex Downs, but the war changes them both. When George returns from the front, he is not the same as the boy she knewand Amelia must decide whether love is something that can survive the changes people undergo. With elements of nostalgia, nature, and emotional transformation, the story reflects on how war impacts identity, relationships, and what home means.

Betrayal, ambition, and the struggle for personal success amid the shimmering promise and cruelties of fame are central. The story balances romance, tragedy, competition, and the cost of pursuing dreams in a cut-throat industry

Title: A Game of Thrones
Author: George R.R. Martin
Series Name: A Song of Ice and Fire
Description: A Game of Thrones is the first book in A Song of Ice and Fire. It introduces the reader to the Seven Kingdoms of Westerosa realm of noble houses vying for power, honor, and survival. The story alternates between multiple point-of-view characters: the honorable Ned Stark, the Politicalschemers Lannister family, exiled Targaryens, and others. Beyond politics, there are supernatural threats lurking in the north beyond the Wall, and Daenerys Targaryen’s journey across the sea. The novel is known for complex characters, moral ambiguity, betrayal, vivid world-building, and unexpected twists.

Title: A Storm of Swords
Author: George R.R. Martin
Series Name: A Song of Ice and Fire
Description: This is the third installment in A Song of Ice and Fire. The war for the Iron Throne intensifies; shocking betrayals occur; alliances shift dangerously and enormous consequences emerge (the “Red Wedding” is a pivotal moment). Characters like Arya, Jaime, Jon Snow, and Daenerys undergo dramatic arcs, faced with betrayal, moral compromise, and growing threats both earthly and supernatural. The novel deepens the themes of power, loss, honor, and the costs of ambition.

Title: A Dance with Dragons
Author: George R.R. Martin
Series Name: A Song of Ice and Fire
Description: A Dance with Dragons overlaps in timeline with A Feast for Crows, but shifts back to focus on characters like Daenerys, Jon Snow, Tyrion, and others. It explores the costs of rule and rebellion, the burdens of expectations, and creeping threats both supernatural (from north of the Wall) and human (Politicalbetrayal, war-fatigue). The novel mixes battlefield tension, Politicalplotting, Spiritualand prophetic themes. Fans often see this volume as a return to the broader scope and action of the earlier books.

Title: A Clash of Kings
Author: George R.R. Martin
Series Name: A Song of Ice and Fire
Description: After the events of A Game of Thrones, six claimant kings vie for the Iron Throne amid civil strife in Westeros. Meanwhile, supernatural dangers gather beyond the Wall, and Daenerys Targaryen continues her quest to reclaim her birthright across the sea. The novel expands on Politicalintrigue, betrayal, and shifting loyalties. Martin introduces additional viewpoint characters, expanding the scope of warfare, magic, and moral ambiguity as all sides make costly choices.

Title: A Feast for Crows
Author: George R.R. Martin
Series Name: A Song of Ice and Fire
Description: A Feast for Crows is the fourth book in A Song of Ice and Fire. It deals with the aftermath of the War of the Five Kings: power vacuums, Politicalintrigue, and the struggle for stability in Westeros. Some viewpoint characters’ stories take a backseat, while new ones emerge, especially among the Iron Islands and Dorne. Themes of succession, identity, betrayal, and survival are central. The novel is slower-paced than earlier ones, focusing more on Politicalmaneuvering than full-scale battles.

A stylish blend of mystery, magic, and youthful intrigue that birthed one of Aoyama’s early iconic works.

A charming mix of mystery, magic, and youthful wit that deepens the intrigue.

Title: Magic Kaito Vol. 4

Title: The Hobbit
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
Description: The Hobbit, subtitled There and Back Again, is a children’s/fantasy novel set in Tolkien’s Middle-earth. It follows Bilbo Baggins, a comfort-loving hobbit, who is reluctantly swept into a quest led by Gandalf and a band of dwarves to reclaim their homeland and treasure from the dragon Smaug. Along the way Bilbo discovers courage, cleverness, and a mysterious ring with powerful implications. The story balances adventure, humor, and mythic elements, laying groundwork for The Lord of the Rings.

Title: The Fellowship of the Ring
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
Description: The Fellowship of the Ring is the first volume of The Lord of the Rings. It begins with the peaceful life of hobbits in the Shire, but soon escalates as Frodo Baggins inherits the One Ring and learns of its evil power. A fellowship of representatives of the Free Peoples is formedhobbits, men, an elf, a dwarf, and a wizardto help Frodo journey toward Mount Doom to destroy the Ring. The book mixes epic landscapes, mythic backstory, Politicaltensions, and personal sacrifices. It introduces core themes of friendship, courage, corruption, and destiny.

Title: The Two Towers
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
Description: The Two Towers continues the journey begun in The Fellowship of the Ring, splitting the Fellowship into different paths: Frodo and Sam move toward Mordor, while Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli pursue Merry and Pippin. The stakes intensify with battles, treachery (notably Saruman’s betrayal), and the growing influence of evil in Middle-earth. The book builds tension via a dual narrative structure, exploring themes of loyalty, corruption, hope, and the burdens of destiny. Tolkien’s combination of heroic fantasy, expansive world-building, and introspective character moments makes this volume a crucial, dramatic middle chapter in the trilogy.

Title: The Return of the King
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
Description: The Return of the King is the final volume of The Lord of the Rings, culminating the epic conflict against Sauron. It follows the climactic Siege of Minas Tirith, the journey of Frodo and Sam into Mordor, and the ultimate fate of the One Ring. After the great battle and victory, there remains the emotional aftermath: the return to the Shire, confronting changes to home, and the toll of power and sacrifice. Tolkien concludes with the crowning of Aragorn, the bittersweet departures of beloved characters, and reflections on mortality, friendship, and the passing of an age.

Title: The Silmarillion
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien
Description: The Silmarillion is a mythic history of Tolkien’s universe, covering the creation of the world (Ainulindalë), the shaping of the Valar and Maiar, the fate of the Silmarils, the rise and fall of Númenor, and stories of Elves, Men, and their struggles across Ages. It is less a continuous narrative than a collection of legendary tales, genealogies, and epic events that form the background for The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings. Tolkien’s son, Christopher Tolkien, edited and compiled the manuscripts after Tolkien’s death to bring coherence to the vast and sometimes fragmentary mythology. The language is more formal, the tone solemn, and the structure more complex than the LOTR trilogy, but it rewards readers with depth, tragedy, beauty, and scale.
